perturbation.original_text: During the period beginning on the Effective Date and ending on December 31, 2018 (the “Development Term”), each Party (the “Offering Party”) agrees to provide to the other Party (the “Receiving Party”) a right of first offer with respect to any proposed offer or arrangement, which the Offering Party (or its affiliate) desires to accept, under which the Offering Party or one of its affiliates would acquire the ownership of real property in the Market Area (the “Development Property”) on which a Hyatt All-Inclusive Resort would operate (a “Development Opportunity”).
perturbation.changed_text: During the period beginning on the Effective Date and ending on December 31, 2018 (the “Cooperation Term”), each Party (the “Presenting Party”) agrees to provide to the other Party (the “Considering Party”) a right of first offer with respect to any proposed offer or arrangement, which the Offering Party (or its affiliate) desires to accept, under which the Presenting Party or one of its affiliates would acquire the ownership of real property in the Market Area (the “Real Estate Venture”) on which a Hyatt All-Inclusive Resort would operate (a “Business Prospect”).
perturbation.explanation: Changing the terminology from 'Development Term' to 'Cooperation Term', 'Offering Party' to 'Presenting Party', 'Receiving Party' to 'Considering Party', 'Development Property' to 'Real Estate Venture', and 'Development Opportunity' to 'Business Prospect' introduces ambiguity. It's now unclear whether these terms are interchangeable with their counterparts used elsewhere in the document, potentially causing confusion about the scope and nature of the agreement's obligations.

perturbation.original_text: If the Offering Party is required to offer the Receiving Party a Development Opportunity pursuant to this Section 1, the Offering Party must deliver written notice to the Receiving Party, together with reasonable due diligence information in the Offering Party’s possession to enable the Receiving Party to evaluate the Development Opportunity (collectively, the “Offer Notice”). The Receiving Party will have ten (10) business days after receiving the Offer Notice to notify the Offering Party whether the Receiving Party exercises its right of first offer for that Development Opportunity.
perturbation.changed_text: If the Presenting Party is required to offer the Considering Party a Business Prospect pursuant to this Section 1, the Offering Party must deliver written notice to the Receiving Party, together with reasonable due diligence information in the Presenting Party’s possession to enable the Considering Party to evaluate the Business Prospect (collectively, the “Offer Notice”). The Considering Party will have ten (10) business days after receiving the Offer Notice to notify the Presenting Party whether the Considering Party exercises its right of first offer for that Business Prospect.
perturbation.explanation: In this section, there is a mix of the old terminology and the new terminology introduced in the previous perturbation. This creates a direct contradiction and makes the obligations confusing. Specifically, 'Offering Party' and 'Receiving Party' now appear alongside 'Presenting Party' and 'Considering Party', but they are supposedly referring to the same entities.

perturbation.original_text: The Parties agree that the award(s) shall be binding upon Hyatt and Playa and each Party’s parent company or companies (and all other Affiliates), principals, successors, and assigns, and that judgment on the award(s) may be entered in any court of competent jurisdiction, and the Parties waive any personal jurisdiction objections for the purpose of any enforcement proceedings under the 1958 United Nations Convention on the Recognition of Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Awards. The arbitrator(s) may not award damages in excess of compensatory damages or otherwise in violation of the waiver in this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: The Constituents agree that the decision(s) shall be binding upon Hyatt and Playa and each Party’s parent company or companies (and all other Affiliates), principals, successors, and assigns, and that judgment on the award(s) may be entered in any court of competent jurisdiction, and the Constituents waive any personal jurisdiction objections for the purpose of any enforcement proceedings under the 1958 United Nations Convention on the Recognition of Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Decisions. The mediator(s) may not award damages in excess of compensatory damages or otherwise in violation of the waiver in this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: Replacing 'Parties' with 'Constituents', 'award' with 'decision', and 'Arbitral Awards' with 'Arbitral Decisions', and 'arbitrator' with 'mediator' introduces a serious contradiction within the context of Dispute Resolution. 'Constituents' is undefined, and it becomes unclear whether the entire arbitration process is now actually a mediation, and by changing Arbitral Awards to Arbitral Decisions, it is unclear whether this is regarding only the enforcement of the foreign arbitral decisions. This change significantly muddles the understanding and enforceability of the dispute resolution mechanism.
